content:
Hey following up on improving our calendar situation, and I went ahead an set up a nextcloud instance to test out making a complete calendar for the rust-lang org. Here's what I have so far. This includes the compiler team google calendar and custom events for the rest of teams since it was hard to find the links to their calendars. It's definitely missing some teams.

https://cloud.rewrite.in.rs/apps/calendar/p/LZ7LyH5Piq6bmL3L-coMmmqy4dQCGKY62-gK3seE28webFswaG-ZFCPdksTt9C4JkXX-zKazYeAP4bYwnDya-eAw8zYfFYZZ2PP36-GL7iLCzNP6akwALE-b9FTPoPLtarCEDxn/dayGridMonth/now
tbh I'm not thrilled to self-host things on our infra
if we can get calendars in a managed environment (even sponsored) I'd be way more happy
the maintenance work is not trivial, especially with upgrades and backups
and in infra we're trying to reduce the work we need to do to maintain our services

@Pietro Albini There's no reason we couldn't have a managed instance. That is possible, I made my own instance because that's the quickest way for us try it out without paying, or committing to anything.
fwiw, it took like 15 minutes to setup. It took longer to setup the domain (which I bought for a separate idea but haven't gotten around to yet.)
yep, but we need to setup backups, periodically check they work, keep the instance up to date...
Again, I would also prefer if we had a managed instance. Those are available.
We could even try to have it donated/discounted for us.
But we have to know if we would even use it first, before we think about how we maintain it.

On the topic of the calendar itself. An important feature to me in nextcloud that I haven't been able to find any other calendar service is having a public link containing multiple calendars. The link is just combination of all the calendars shown on the left sidebar. Which means that you can have different calendars with different people and permissions adding events while having a single place that people can see everything.

This is also embeddable, so it would actually be possible to have the team schedule for a given week or month on the website or forge directly. People could easily see what meetings are happening.

And we can easily have calendars that bigger or smaller depending on the context. For example this link also shows the community events that are happening.

https://cloud.rewrite.in.rs/apps/calendar/p/LZ7LyH5Piq6bmL3L-coMmmqy4dQCGKY62-gK3seE28webFswaG-ZFCPdksTt9C4JkXX-zKazYeAP4bYwnDya-eAw8zYfFYZZ2PP36-GL7iLCzNP6akwALE-b9FTPoPLtarCEDxn-oskxyYDxiXjDxHtN/dayGridMonth/now

@BatmanAoD (Kyle Strand) I believe that's because they were all created by the admin account.
Because you could have "Compiler Team (alice)" and "Compiler Team (bob)" calendars for example.
Ah, okay. It would be nice if that could be hidden, since most users probably don't need to know who created the calendar, but I don't know if this calendar service has an option for that

Oh yeah, here's links to the calendars source and docs. Some of the docs are bit out of date as some of these features are new.

  • Calendar Repo: https://github.com/nextcloud/calendar
  • Calendar Docs: https://docs.nextcloud.com/server/18/user_manual/pim/calendar.html#

I couldn't find anything in the existing issues list, documentation, or forum about such a feature, so I went ahead and filed an issue: https://github.com/nextcloud/calendar/issues/2056
link to t-compiler's calendar is at https://rust-lang.github.io/compiler-team/#meeting-calendar

I liked the idea

@spacekookie I haven't pushed for it, mainly because I haven't had the time fill it out more and discuss it. If there was something other nextcloud I would probably use that, but I haven't found any other calendar software that lets you display multiple calendars in a single view like that.
I think nextcloud is probably a good candidate because getting a hosted instance is quite easy
:+1:
I have to say
that it would be really nice to have something equivalent to google docs
but where the teams and access control maps to Rust teams/working-groups/etc
does nextcloud support "message boards" of any kind, @XAMPPRocky? (I know we have internals, just curious)

@nikomatsakis It does have a kind of message board. It definitely has messaging (and calls) for people internal to the instance and it has a third party app that enables the instance to act as a federated social network like Mastodon. https://github.com/nextcloud/social

but where the teams and access control maps to Rust teams/working-groups/etc

Nextcloud can definitely handle this, it has a lot of features in this regard. If you're familiar with old Google Plus "Circles" it has that which lets you provide permissions to a group. It does also have OpenID/OAuth login available. The main work would be figuring out how to allow that to map to rust-lang/team.
btw yeah over time I've been feeling like this is something we need, especially with a gdocs-like solution that's integrated with the team repo
